reviewText: I love the older horror movies. They were mysterious not tragic but effective with great actors from the past. All these will make things go bump when you least expect it!
Some of my favorite horror films are on this!

Hard to top Annie Van Auken's review here, so I won't even try.

Excellent nostalgia horror viewing collection -- my mother wouldn't let me watch these when I was a child because she was sure that I'd have nightmares (that was my brother), and they'd stunt my growth, or something.  So of course I watch them now, and have even fallen asleep on the sofa watching these ( my insomnia thanks them).

I doubt jaded younger viewers would bat an eyelash at these today, but they do have their charms, imo -- but then, Turner Classic Movie channel is one of the top 5 watched in my household.  If you are looking for slasher films with pounding 'music', these aren't for you.

PD purveyor TGG DIRECT offers reliable DVD transfers of unrestored films at bargain prices. Some extras are included but what's NOT here are any annoying on-screen company watermarks. Their 15 film HORROR COLLECTION is typical public domain stuff. All have been in wide circulation for decades, yet several here are considered classics of the genre. My favorite: Roger Corman's BUCKET OF BLOOD, the tongue-in-cheek story of a beatnik club nobody whose lifelike statues make him a celebrity. What his fans don't know however is the artist's "works" were once alive! As good as "Bucket" is, Corman's THE TERROR is just as dreadful. Shot by at least two directors, it's a disjointed mess that features a young Nicholson and elderly Karloff. SCARED TO DEATH has a minor role for little Angelo Rossitto, aka the top half of "Master Blaster" in MAD MAX BEYOND THUNDERDOME (1985). Perhaps all fright film aficionados are familiar with NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD and CARNIVAL OF SOULS, classics that are more popular today than they were 45 or 50 years ago. Both were feature film debut masterpieces for directors George Romero ("Living Dead") and Herk Hervey ("Carnival"). In Herk's case, this was his ONLY full length picture; quite an achievement for an industrial short film maker. You can call DISC THREE a Vincent Price Festival. All are excellent, especially THE LAST MAN ON EARTH, a spaghetti frighter shot in Rome. SHOCK! has its tense moments but is more film noir than horror. HOUSE ON HAUNTED HILL is by legendary 'B' movie producer/writer/director/promoter William Castle. Arguably his best work, it's the story of a group of folks who are each promised a tidy cash payment if they can survive the night in their host's creepy mansion. After Francis Coppola did some uncredited second unit directing on Corman's "Terror," he was rewarded with his own project. The result was less than sterling. DEMENTIA 13 is an ax murder frighter scripted by Coppola. Way down on the cast list of THE BAT is former Little Rascals cutie Darla Hood. Based on the 1920 Broadway stage production, this one's "When it flies, someone dies!" tag doesn't bode well for Alfalfa's former girlfriend. Parenthetical numbers preceding titles are 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll ratings. DISC ONE (8.0) Night of the Living Dead (1968) - Duane Jones/Judith O'Dea/Karl Hardman/Marilyn Eastman/Keith Wayne/Judith Ridley (5.6) Dementia 13 (1963) - William Campbell/Luana Anders/Bart Patton/Patrick Magee/Mary Mitchel/Eithne Dunne/Peter Read (6.2) I Bury the Living (1958) - Richard Boone/Theodore Bikel/Peggy Maurer/Howard Smith/Herbert Anderson/Robert Osterloh DISC TWO (7.0) Carnival of Souls (1962) - Candace Hilligoss/Frances Feist/Sidney Berger/Art Ellison/Tom McGinnis (6.8) Horror Hotel ("City of the Dead") (UK-1960) - Dennis Lotis/Christopher Lee/Patricia Jessel/Tom Naylor (4.8) Last Woman on Earth (1960) - Betsy Jones-Moreland/Antony Carbone/Robert Towne DISC THREE (6.8) House on Haunted Hill (1959) - Vincent Price/Carol Ohmart/Richard Long/Alan Marshal/Carolyn Craig/Elisha Cook Jr. (6.8) The Last Man on Earth (Italy/USA-1964) - Vincent Price/Franca Bettoia/Emma Danieli/Giacomo Rossi-Stuart (6.1) Shock (1946) - Vincent Price/Lynn Bari/Frank Latimore/Anabel Shaw/Reed Hadley/Charles Trowbridge DISC FOUR (3.7) Scared to Death (1947) - Bela Lugosi/George Zucco/Nat Pendleton/Joyce Compton/Stanley Andrews/Angelo Rossitto (6.7) A Bucket of Blood (1959) - Dck Miller/Barboura Morris/Antony Carbone/Ed Nelson/Bert Convy/Bruno VeSota (5.8) The Bat (1959) - Vincent Price/Agnes Moorehead/Gavin Gordon/John Sutton/Lenita Lane/Elaine Edwards/Darla Hood DISC FIVE (3.5) A Name for Evil (1973) - Robert Culp/Samantha Eggar/Sheila Sullivan/Mike Lane/Sue Hathaway/Ted Greenhalgh (5.1) Silent Night, Bloody Night (1972) - Patrick O'Neal/James Patterson/Mary Woronov/Astrid Heeren/John Carradine (4.9) The Terror (1963) - Boris Karloff/Jack Nicholson/Sandra Knight/Dck Miller/Dorothy Neumann/Jonathan Haze
